It`s always hard to assign "fair" wages on the labour market. There is only supply and demand, and manipulation thereoff. It becomes extra difficult in cases of monopoly markets as well as wages in public service. I find it peculiar that public services seems to be almost better payed in the US than the private sphere. Is this just my impression, or is this the case? Usually it`s the other way around* since public service markets are characterised by an employer monopsomy that is able to hold down the wages below average wages in the private sphere where competition between individual firms will raise the wages.
 
 * there are certain exceptions where loyalty, job insecurity or the fear of corruption in the public service sphere may drive the wages upwards instead, but this only applies to very specific proffesions (like police, judges, high level beurocrats and directors, politicians etc, etc.
